title: January 2013 Licensure Paper Three
description: NCK January 2013 Paper Three Licensure Examination covering Community Health Nursing, Mental Health & Midwifery (Part I MCQs).

questions.question: The term that best describes a group to invasion and spread of an infectious agent is:
questions.explanation: Herd immunity (or community immunity) describes the resistance of a group or community to the invasion and spread of an infectious agent. This occurs when a significant portion of the population is immune, thereby providing protection to unimmunized individuals.
questions.hint: Think about the resistance of a 'group' or 'community' rather than a single person.

questions.question: The frequency of a phenomenon during a given time and which deals with both new and old cases is:
questions.explanation: Prevalence rate measures the total number of existing cases (both new and old) of a disease in a population at a specific point in time. Incidence rate refers only to new cases.
questions.hint: This rate looks at the total burden of disease (existing + new) existing at a specific time.

questions.question: Demographic data describes:

options.text: Characteristics and distribution of people in a given area and the changes in the population over time.
Any data that delineate health or health related events.
Adoption, annulment patterns of the population.
The extent and distribution of illness in a community.

questions.explanation: Demography is the statistical study of populations, including their size, structure (characteristics like age, sex, ethnicity), and distribution, as well as changes in these parameters over time due to birth, migration, and aging.
questions.hint: Think about the root word 'demos' meaning people/population.

questions.question: Emergency contraceptives are effective if taken within:
questions.explanation: Levonorgestrel-based emergency contraceptive pills are generally licensed for use within 72 hours (3 days) of unprotected intercourse to be most effective.
questions.hint: The standard window for ECPs is 3 days.

questions.question: According to Erikson’s psychosocial development tasks, industry v/s inferiority occurs at:
questions.explanation: The stage of Industry vs. Inferiority corresponds to the school-age child, typically ages 5/6 to 12 years. During this stage, children learn to be competent and productive.
questions.hint: This stage corresponds to the primary school years.

questions.question: Cross sectional surveys give:
questions.explanation: Cross-sectional surveys collect data at a single point in time, providing a 'snapshot' of a population. This design is ideal for measuring prevalence.
questions.hint: Since it takes a snapshot at one point in time, it sees what exists now (prevalence) rather than new cases over time.

questions.question: Principles of primary health care include:

options.text: Intersectorial action, integration of health programmes, education concerning prevailing health problems
Maternal child health care and family planning, immunization, proper nutrition

questions.explanation: The fundamental principles of PHC are Equity, Community Participation, Intersectoral Coordination, and Appropriate Technology (often facilitated by decentralization). Option 'a' best captures these structural principles.
questions.hint: Look for the option that lists broad structural principles rather than specific service elements like MCH or water.

questions.question: The correct sequence of community diagnosis process is:

options.text: Planning the survey, community inventory, developing and pre testing survey tools, execution of the survey, data analysis, report writing, dissemination and community action
Community inventory, planning the survey, developing and pre testing survey tools, execution of the survey, data analysis, report writing, dissemination and community action
Developing and pre testing survey tools, planning the survey, execution of the survey, data analysis, report writing, dissemination and community action
Community inventory, developing and pre testing survey tools, planning the survey, execution of the survey, data analysis, report writing, dissemination and community action

questions.explanation: The process begins with planning/initiation (defining objectives), followed by community inventory/reconnaissance, then tool development, execution, analysis, and finally dissemination.
questions.hint: You must Plan before you can take an Inventory or develop tools.

questions.question: The non-probability sampling methods include:

options.text: Cluster sampling, quota sampling and systematic sampling
Convenience sampling technique, cluster sampling and quota sampling
Simple random sampling, systematic sampling and cluster sampling
Convenience sampling, quota sampling, purposive sampling

questions.explanation: Non-probability sampling methods include Convenience, Quota, Purposive (Judgmental), and Snowball sampling. Cluster and Systematic sampling are probability methods.
questions.hint: Look for the option where selection is NOT random.

questions.question: The child understands a few words and tries to use them at:
questions.explanation: By 9-12 months, an infant typically understands simple instructions and begins to say their first single words (like 'mama', 'dada').
questions.hint: This coincides with the time many babies start walking or standing.

questions.question: Tooth eruption in children is likely to occur at:
questions.explanation: The first primary teeth (usually the lower central incisors) typically erupt around 6 months (approx 24 weeks) of age.
questions.hint: Think about the age when weaning/complementary feeding usually starts.

questions.question: Specific pharmacological management of ophthalmia neonatorum according to NASCOP flow chart of ophthalmia neonatorum includes:

options.text: Procaine penicillin 300,000 IU IM and 1% tetracycline eye ointment TDS X 10 days
Streptomycin 1% eye ointment, procaine penicillin 300,000 IU IM
Septrin 5 mg stat, 1% eye ointment tetracycline
Procaine penicillin 300,000 IU IM and streptomycin 1% eye ointment

questions.explanation: Based on older NASCOP guidelines referenced in this 2013 paper, management included systemic Procaine Penicillin IM plus topical Tetracycline eye ointment. (Note: Modern guidelines may differ).
questions.hint: The treatment requires both a systemic antibiotic (IM) and a topical eye ointment.

questions.question: ‘Pulse’ saturation vaccination implies:

options.text: A method used when static MCH services are too far away for mothers to bring their infants for immunization
Coverage of susceptible population with immunization
Few susceptible due to increased immunization

questions.explanation: 'Pulse' immunization refers to the simultaneous mass administration of vaccines to a target population to 'saturate' the population and break the chain of transmission.
questions.hint: Think of a 'pulse' as a concentrated burst of activity covering everyone at once.

questions.question: Gross reproductive rate is:

options.text: Number of live births per 1000 workers in specific age group
Total number of children born to a woman
Average number of girls born to a woman with current fertility pattern
Number of daughters a new born girl will bear during her life time

questions.explanation: The Gross Reproduction Rate (GRR) is the average number of daughters a woman would have if she survived through her childbearing years, following current age-specific fertility rates.
questions.hint: Focus on the gender of the children in this rate—it specifically tracks female births.

questions.question: Stable litter contains mainly:

options.text: Animal droppings and left over animal feeds
Large proportions of purtriscible vegetables and broken glasses
Iron pieces, dead animals, animal droppings

questions.explanation: Stable litter refers to refuse from animal stables, primarily consisting of bedding, manure (droppings), and leftover feed.
questions.hint: Think about what you would find on the floor of a stable where animals live.

questions.question: The permanent hardness of water can be removed by:
questions.explanation: Permanent hardness is removed by adding Sodium Carbonate (Washing Soda) or by ion exchange. Option 'c' (sodium bicarbonate) is accepted in the context of this paper as the chemical agent.
questions.hint: Boiling only removes temporary hardness. You need a chemical agent for permanent hardness.

questions.question: In epidemiology chi-square (x²) is:

options.text: An attempt to establish relationship between two categorical variables
A type of analysis to find out whether an independent variable predicts a given dependent variables
A technique that deals with one independent and one dependent variable
An attempt to determine whether a group of variables together predicts a given dependent variable

questions.explanation: The Chi-square test is a statistical test used to determine if there is a significant association (relationship) between two categorical variables.
questions.hint: This test works with categories (like Yes/No, Red/Blue), not continuous numbers.

questions.question: The situation where subjects’ awareness of being in an experimental group motivates them to perform better is known as:
questions.explanation: The Hawthorne effect refers to the alteration of behavior by the subjects of a study due to their awareness of being observed.
questions.hint: Named after the 'Hawthorne' Works plant where the study took place.

questions.question: Match the following diseases with their causative organism or vector:
questions.explanation: Onchocerciasis is transmitted by the Simulium damnosum (black fly). Louse-borne relapsing fever is transmitted by Pediculus corporis (body louse).
questions.hint: Match the specific vector to the disease.

questions.question: Refrigeration preserves food by killing all bacteria.
questions.explanation: Refrigeration is bacteriostatic, meaning it slows down the growth and reproduction of bacteria, but it does not kill them.
questions.hint: Think about whether bacteria can start growing again once food warms up.
